history.content: The fact that you may see multiple results, is a sign that most of your questions have already been asked as well as answered multiple times, there's no real substitute for keeping up with the piazza conversation As for how you test your input for task 1, testInput.txt & testOutput.txt are defaults, there's no need to specify the default input, while the output is not strictly necessary aside from debugging; beyond that, you kind of need to read the code to confirm that your own implementation for task 1 would 'just work' with the default config, although it is quite feasible that it should as long as you code it properly.

The fact that you may see multiple results, is a sign that most of your questions have already been asked as well as answered multiple times, there's no real substitute for keeping up with the piazza conversation

children.subject:
Isn't genhashes just  a random hash generator we code for task 1 and task 3 and it runs when genHashes is to "True" and generate random hash values. 

testInput.txt contains a set of 200000 test values ( x's )  we could use ( at least I thought we could )  for Task 1 and Task 3 to generate the graphs. Or are we supposed to generate our own set of test inputs ( Xs ) for Task 1 and Task 3 and not use testInput.txt??.
yes you may use the given input data for tasks 1 and 3.  however, you also need to generate data for task 1 that is correlated in some way.

John,

Thanks for the quick feedback Also. the instructions say - Compare how they perform using data drawn randomly from the universe to how well they perform with data having some correlation (for example, data in a sequence, like “first 2m even numbers entered”).

so 1. data drawn randomly from the universe  - Would the testInput.txt qualify for this criteria?

2. data having some correlation (for example, data in a sequence, like “first 2m even numbers entered”) - We generate this or something similar.

Also what data do you suggest we use for testing task 3. 

Thanks!!

1) 'k' should be = 1 for task 1, =13 for task 2 (although you will not have to set this, as the import function john wrote will do this for you), and k varies between .4*c and c for task 3.

 

2) (a, b) should be calculated at random for task 1 (although feel free to manually test specific values - its not required but I did to see how I could break one of the hashes)

 

3) For task 1 and 3, you can set n to be whatever you wish (JUST MAKE SURE ITS A PRIME NUMBER); for task 2, this is set for you automatically.

 

4) For me, I found it best to actually write the hashes, complete task 2, and then go back to task 1 to finish the remainder of task 1.

 

5) testInput.txt is not used for task 1 or task 3; you should be generating random numbers on your own for this (that is to say, genHashes = True when you initialize your hashes for tasks 1 and 3).

To test task 2, you can run both of these commands:

./bloom.py -c testConfigHashType1.txt -i testInput.txt -o testOutput.txt -v validResHashType1.txt
./bloom.py -c testConfigHashType2.txt -i testInput.txt -o testOutput.txt -v validResHashType2.txt

That will test both hashes for task 2, and you should get a message saying they work as expected.

For tasks 1 and 3, there is no test per se but you can run them a la (after you write them, that is):

./bloom.py -t 1 <leave everything else the same>
./bloom.py -t 3 <leave everything else the same>

history.content:
I am just starting this project and have several questions in Task 1 itself.

1) What should 'k' be? i.e. how many hash functions should I have?

2) What should 'a' and 'b' be in random.randint(a, b) for Task 1?

3) What should 'n' be?

4) How should I test my implementation for Task1?

5) My assumption: I would be using the testInput.txt file for testing Task 1 and that the command would be

./bloom.py -i testInput.txt -o myoutput.txt -t 1

Is the above right? myoutput.txt would contain hash outputs for each hash function for each number read from the file. Is this right?

I really wish all these were clearly specified in the PDF document.
history.subject: Task1 questions
